introduction.text: Immunology is the study of the body’s defense mechanisms that protect against infections, eliminate abnormal cells, and maintain tolerance to self. The immune system includes organs, cells, and soluble factors that identify and neutralize harmful agents such as microbes, toxins, and cancer cells.
pediatricsImportance: Infants have immature immunity and are more prone to infections.
Understanding immune development helps guide vaccine planning and infection control.
Immune-based disorders like primary immunodeficiency, allergies, autoimmunity, and Kawasaki disease are commonly seen in children.

divisions.adaptive: slower but specific, with memory (e.g., antibodies, T-cells)

vaccine.definition: A vaccine is a biological preparation that induces active acquired immunity by stimulating the body’s immune system to recognize and combat specific pathogens or their components.
purpose: To prevent infectious diseases by generating specific protective antibodies
To create herd immunity within the community
To reduce morbidity, mortality, and disease-related complications
To control and eventually eradicate vaccine-preventable diseases

types.description: Contains parts of the pathogen + protein carrier
Contains genetic code to produce antigens

liveAttenuated.remember: Live Attenuated Vaccines — "My Best Friend Rides On Small Yellow Train"

primary.boneMarrow: where all blood cells (including immune cells) are produced. B cells mature here.

secondary.lymphNodes: trap antigens from tissues and activate lymphocytes.
secondary.spleen: filters blood and responds to blood-borne pathogens.
secondary.MALT: mucosa-associated lymphoid tissues (tonsils, Peyer’s patches, appendix).

innate: Macrophages/Monocytes – engulf pathogens and present antigens.
Natural killer (NK) cells – kill virus-infected or tumor cells.
Eosinophils and Basophils – deal with parasites and allergies.
adaptive: B lymphocytes – produce antibodies when activated.

molecules: Antibodies (Immunoglobulins) – proteins made by B cells that bind to specific antigens (types: IgG, IgA, IgM, IgE, IgD).
Cytokines and Chemokines – chemical messengers that modulate immune responses.
Complement system – group of proteins that help antibodies and phagocytes clear microbes.
MHC (Major Histocompatibility Complex) – molecules that present antigens to T cells; MHC I and II.

chemical: enzymes in saliva and tears (like lysozyme)
biological: normal flora that competes with pathogens

typesOfImmunity.innate: present from birth, immediate response, no memory.
typesOfImmunity.adaptive: specific response, has memory, develops after exposure to antigens.
